qas.question: How long can it take to create a DBMS?
Name three DBMSs that have been used since the 1970s.
How is the cost to create a DBMS distributed?

answers.text: spread over a large number of users

qas.question: Name an example of a general-purpose DBMS.
How long can it take to search for a DBMS?
What are three DBMSs that have been used during the 1960s?

plausible_answers.text: spread over a large number of users

qas.question: How is the cost to remove a DBMS distributed?
What is always the optimal solution to manage databases?

context: A DBMS has evolved into a complex software system and its development typically requires <a0_0><b4_0>thousands of human years<b4_0/><a0_0/> of development effort.[a] Some general-purpose DBMSs such as <a1_0><b5_0>Adabas, Oracle and DB2<b5_0/><a1_0/> have been undergoing upgrades since the 1970s. General-purpose DBMSs aim to meet the needs of as many applications as possible, which adds to the complexity. However, the fact that their development cost can be <a2_0><b6_0>spread over a large number of users<b6_0/><a2_0/> means that they are often the most cost-effective approach. However, <b7_0>a general-purpose DBMS<b7_0/> is not always the optimal solution: in some cases a general-purpose DBMS may introduce unnecessary overhead. Therefore, there are many examples of systems that use special-purpose databases. A common example is <a3_0>an email system<a3_0/> that performs many of the functions of a general-purpose DBMS such as the insertion and deletion of messages composed of various items of data or associating messages with a particular email address; but these functions are limited to what is required to handle email and don't provide the user with all of the functionality that would be available using a general-purpose DBMS.
